Due to the versatility of metalated COFs, multiple therapeutic agents can be integrated to realize multimodal combination therapy. According to the report of Dong et al., bifunctional CuS@COF-BDP nanomaterials were obtained by introducing ultrasmall CuS into TPB-DMTP-COF using copper acetate and thioacetamide as starting materials, followed by covalent modification of the amino groups on the TPB-DMTP-COF surface with a boron-dipyrromethene (BODIPY) photosensitizer.837 Upon 520 nm laser irradiation, CuS@COF-BDP induces 1O2 generation for PDT. Upon 1064 nm laser irradiation, CuS@COF-BDP leads to an increase in the temperature of the illuminated region for PTT because of its near-infrared light absorption and photothermal conversion ability. PDT and PTT synergistically cause significant lethality against MCF-7 breast cancer in vitro and in vivo.

Gold nanomaterials are considered as promising multifunctional therapeutic agents due to their photothermal properties and catalytic activity.838 Gold nanomaterial-loaded COFs are potential multimodal therapeutic platforms that are easy to further functionalize. As reported by the Tang group in 2021, CApHD nanosheets were obtained by in situ growth of gold nanoparticles on a photosensitive porphyrin-COF, followed by loading with DOX and covalent modification with a pH-responsive insertion peptide.839 As expected, CApHD induced the upregulation of reactive oxygen species and local overheating upon 635 nm laser irradiation, which disrupted cell membrane integrity and promoted DOX release and entry into tumor cells, ultimately enabling cell membrane-targeted synergetic PDT, PTT and chemotherapy. In addition, in 2021, Lin et al. prepared a COF-Au-MnO2-HA composite with catalytic cascade reaction activity by growing gold nanoparticles and MnO2 sequentially on TPB-DMTP-COF for T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging and combination therapy of hypoxic tumors.326 The authors demonstrated that the gold nanoparticles catalyze the glucose oxidation to generate gluconic acid and H2O2 and MnO2 subsequently decomposes the generated H2O2 into O2 for enhancing PDT.

In addition to CuS and Au, other types of nanomaterials embedded in COFs have also been reported. Recently, CaCO3-loaded COFs have been used for calcium overload-induced tumor therapy.375,840 As reported by Dong et al.,375 using the reaction of CaCl2 and NH4HCO3, CaCO3@COF-BODIPY-2I was prepared by the in situ formation of ultrasmall CaCO3 in TPB-DMTP-COF modified with a diiodo-substituted BODIPY photosensitizer (Fig. 59).375 Surface modification with glycosaminoglycan further improve the targeting ability of the nanomaterial to tumor cells with high CD44 expression. The obtained CaCO3@COF-BODIPY-2I@GAG induced 1O2 production under green LED light, leading to damage to mitochondria as intracellular calcium buffer pools. In the absence of the calcium buffering capacity of mitochondria, an irreversible defect in ion homeostasis is induced by elevated Ca(II) concentrations due to CaCO3 decomposition in acidic lysosomes, thereby leading to cell death. In the HCT-116 xenograft model, a single injection of CaCO3@COF-BODIPY-2I@GAG and subsequent light exposure almost eradicated the tumor, which showed no obvious signs of recurrence within 12 days. This study shows for the first time the use of metalated COFs in ion interference therapy and highlights the disruptive effect of PDT on cellular homeostasis.


Fig. 59 Metalated COFs for ion interference therapy. (A) Synthesis of CaCO3@COF-BODIPY-2I@GAG. (B) CaCO3@COF-BODIPY-2I@GAG-induced Ca(II) overload and PDT. (C) HCT-116 cell morphological changes caused by 1O2 and Ca(II). Adapted with permission of ref. 375. Copyright © 2020 Wiley-VCH GmbH.

Moreover, the band gap change caused by the composition of TiO2 with COFs may be beneficial for the generation of reactive oxygen species. In 2021, Pang et al. reported that a TiO2-loaded COF nanoagent, which was used for SDT, could be prepared by depositing anatase-phase TiO2 on the DMTP-TAPB-COF surface.363 The energy band gap of COF-TiO2 decreased from 3.15 eV to 2.42 eV compared to pure TiO2. The narrow band gap was beneficial for improving the electron–hole separation efficiency and enhancing 1O2 generation under sonication. To enhance biocompatibility, COF-TiO2 was further modified with hyaluronic acid. In cultured 4T1 cancer cells, the resulting COF-TiO2-HA induced the upregulation of intracellular reactive oxygen species and led to cell death in a concentration-dependent manner under sonication with a frequency of 1.0 MHz and a power density of 1.5 W cm−2. In an in vivo model of 4T1 tumors, COF-TiO2-HA induced apoptosis and inhibited tumor growth. This is the first report of sonosensitized COFs, and it has greatly inspired the study of COF-based SDT. Finally, COF coatings of COF-TiO2-HA can improve pharmacokinetics, increase tumor accumulation, and optimize therapeutic efficacy in tumor-bearing mice.

Overall, research on the oncotherapeutic applications of metalated COFs is still at a very early stage and many persistent challenges and limitations must be considered. First, due to the size limitations of mammalian cells for uptake of therapeutic nanomaterials, which is generally considered to be an upper limit of 200 nm, the morphological controls during the preparation of metalated COFs cannot be neglected. The dispersibility and colloidal stability of metalated COFs in aqueous solutions are one of the major bottlenecks limiting their biologically relevant applications, especially oncotherapy applications. Second, although the current study implies that the acute toxicity of metalated COFs in rodents is negligible, the metabolic process and long-term toxicity of metalated COFs in vivo have not been studied. Third, in theory, metal coordination can change the interaction between the guest and the framework, thereby regulating the uptake and release of the guest, but the significance of such precise regulation in metalated COF-mediated drug delivery has not been given much attention.

3.7.2. Antimicrobials. Infections caused by bacteria represent an important clinical challenge. Compared to tumor cells, bacteria have additional protective membranes (e.g., outer membrane, capsular polysaccharide layer, and cytoderm)841 and tend to form biofilms to escape the effects of antimicrobial agents and host immune responses.842 The overuse and misuse of conventional antibiotics lead to the development of bacteria toward drug-resistant or even multidrug-resistant bacteria, which is a global public health crisis of growing proportions.843 Due to these intrinsic and extrinsic difficulties, the development of bionanomaterial-based antimicrobial therapeutics is an alternative to conventional antibiotics that is gaining attention.787,844 COF-based antimicrobials are highly customizable biomaterials. COFs with intrinsic antibacterial activity can be easily designed and synthesized by introducing antibacterial moieties, including guanidine,845,846 propidium iodide,847 and benzooxazine.848 Additionally, due to their porosity, COFs can be loaded with high levels of antibiotics to provide slow and sustained antibiotic release.849–851 Furthermore, photosensitive COFs induce the generation of reactive oxygen species (including 1O2, ˙O2−, ˙OH, etc.) under light, causing the oxidation of bacterial membrane structures and killing bacteria.852–857 Additionally, COFs can be composited with other antimicrobial nanomaterials, such as Fe-based MOFs,858 MXenes,859 and nanosilver,860 to enhance the adhesion of the biomaterials on the bacterial surface and improve the antimicrobial activity.

Fe-metalated COFs can induce bacterial death by virtue of the chemodynamic activity of Fe(II). In 2021, Xiang et al. reported an antibacterial GFeF material that was synthesized by loading glucose oxidase on iron-metalated Fe-iCOF (Fig. 60).150 The loaded glucose oxidase converted glucose to gluconic acid and H2O2, and then the H2O2 decomposed to ˙OH under the catalysis of Fe-iCOF. The activity of Fe-iCOF was significantly increased in the acidic environment due to gluconic acid. Eventually, the vast accumulation of ˙OH leads to membrane perforation and death of E. coli and S. aureus. Interestingly, the addition of GFeF to a mixture of β-glycerophosphate and chitosan allowed the synthesis of thermosensitive GFeF hydrogels, which inhibited S. aureus infection, promoted vascular endothelial growth factor expression, and reduced inflammatory cell infiltration when used as wound dressings, thereby accelerating wound healing.


Fig. 60 Fe-iCOF as an efficient cascade catalyst for combating bacterial infection and promoting wound healing. (A) Schematic diagram of the cascade reaction. (B) Inhibitory effect of Fe-iCOF and GFeF on S. aureus in the presence or absence of glucose. (C) Wound healing promoted by GFeF in mice infected with S. aureus. Adapted with permission of ref. 150. Copyright © 2021 Wiley-VCH GmbH.

Nanosilver is a traditional broad-spectrum antimicrobial metal material. In 2022, Dong et al. obtained Ag@DhaTph-COOH by loading silver nanoparticles in a porphyrin-based DhaTph-COOH COF (Fig. 61).319 Ag@DhaTph-COOH has photothermal and photodynamic properties that can be combined with nanosilver to enhance the antimicrobial effect. The inactivation efficiency of Ag@DhaTph-COOH exceeded 95% for bacteria (including E. coli and S. aureus) and viruses (including influenza A virus subtype H1N1 and vesicular stomatitis virus) under a laboratory xenon lamp and even real sunlight. In addition, hydroxyl-rich Ag@DhaTph-COOH was cross-linked with isocyanate-terminated polyurethane oligomers, and after it was sprayed onto the surface of nonwoven polyester fabric, a bioprotective mask with a self-sterilized surface was obtained. Bacteria and viruses attached to the mask were inactivated within 60 min under sunlight exposure. The contaminated mask was regenerated by washing with water and ethanol, with no apparent performance loss after 5 repeated uses.


Fig. 61 Nanosilver-loaded DhaTph-COOH COF as the self-sterilized coating of bioprotective mask against bacteria and viruses. Adapted with permission of ref. 319. Copyright © 2022 The Royal Society of Chemistry.

4. Summary and outlook

Although COFs have the advantages of customizability, high stability, and colourful reaction chemistry and have a wide range of applications, they have some inherent limitations in their properties and applications as pure organic materials.128 The morphology control and processability of COFs are difficult due to the low density, large internal space, and interlayer molecular interactions that are much weaker than covalent bonds. For example, the synthesized COF-based membrane is loose and fragile and has poor reusability.861 Furthermore, the synthesis of nanoscale COF particles necessitates an inefficient exfoliation strategy.119,806 In addition, the poor hydrophilicity of COFs increases the mass transfer resistance in aqueous systems, which is limited in sensing, catalysis, and biomedical applications. More critically, the function of COFs is confined to the limited properties caused by the monomers and their stacking, disregarding more than 4/5 of the metal elements in the periodic table. In contrast, the application-oriented porous materials used in gas adsorption and separation,862,863 catalysis,520,864,865 electrochemistry,866 and biomedicine867,868 heavily rely on the properties endowed by metals rather than the organic moieties. In this context, metalated COFs offer an opportunity to balance the structural advantages and functional limitations of COFs, with impeccable porosity, crystallinity, stability, functionality, and tunability. After more than 10 years of development, metalated COFs stand at the intersection of inorganic chemistry and organic chemistry. They are organic–inorganic hybrid materials, much like MOFs, which have been widely developed and have numerous application prospects. However, the development of metalated COFs is still in the stage of raw material collection and faces some systemic challenges.

The coordination chemical environment of the metal unquestionably influences the material properties in metalated COFs. Several issues should be considered when synthesizing metalated COFs. Are there multiple metal ion binding sites in the framework? What is their contribution to the immobilized metal ions? Do metals form clusters through metal–metal and metal–heteroatom bonds? In addition to the framework, what are the other molecules that form coordination bonds with metals? What additional role dos the ubiquitous defects in COFs play in binding metal ions? The answers to these questions will deepen the understanding of the structure–property relationships and may enable function-oriented material design. Furthermore, it is important to note that current characterization techniques are incapable of unambiguously determining the chemical purity, stacking pattern, crystal domain size, defect density, and many other structural features of COFs.86,869–872 Each of these features with uncertainties may impact the interaction of metal ions with COFs, which further complicates the structure–property relationships of metalated COFs.

Theoretical calculations are powerful tools for studying the structure and properties of materials; for example, first-principles calculations, molecular dynamics simulations, and grand canonical Monte Carlo simulations have been applied in the study of the binding sites of light metals in COFs,402 optimization of the unit cell structure of COFs,852 prediction of gas adsorption behaviors,412,873,874 and design and screening of electrocatalysts.532,875,876 However, due to computational bottlenecks, theoretical simulations are usually performed on fragments of COFs, leading to one-sided conclusions. Moreover, even such degraded theoretical calculations are rarely used to optimize the metalation synthesis conditions, catalyst screening, prediction of electronic properties, and material–biointerface interaction studies, although they are logically feasible and very important.

Artificial intelligence is changing research paradigms in various disciplines, including chemistry and materials science, with the ability to predict and discover unknown information by learning from existing datasets.877 Artificial intelligence bypasses the concrete understanding of structure–property relationships, providing a black-box tool for discovering new structures, new properties, and new applications.878–881 Because the COF structure is highly predictable, a database of COF structures has been established based on combinations of known and predicted building blocks. It contains more than 470000 hypothetical materials.99 In addition, a database of real structures based on published data was also initially established.882 These provide training sets for high-throughput screening and machine learning. Adding the metal dimensionality to these established datasets enables the construction of datasets for the study of metalated COFs. There are, however, two main challenges. First, as mentioned above, the binding sites of metal ions in metalated COFs have not been completely identified, which reduces the accuracy of the dataset and thus increases the training and predictive difficulties of machine learning. Second, the COF structure report lacks a unified standard, and the establishment of the dataset has to rely on manual extraction of structural information from the literature and manual proofreading.873,874,882 We strongly recommend that the community unifies the structure reporting standard of COFs and provides machine-readable standardized format files, which can greatly promote the application of data science in exploring the potential of COFs. We believe that it is only a matter of time before artificial intelligence reshapes the study of metalated COFs.

In conclusion, the library of metal ions and organic monomers with suitable coordination sites for the synthesis of metalated COFs is growing as the research proceeds. The field of metalated COFs will continue to be an active and challenging area of research. We hope that this review article will inspire follow-up studies on metalated COFs and even functionalized COFs.

Author contributions

Q. G. and L.-L. Z. contributed equally to this work, including the literature search, writing, and creation of figures and tables. Y.-B. D. supervised and revised the manuscript. All authors were involved in the discussion and critical revision and approved the final version of the manuscript.
